title: ‘Still a very dangerous storm’: Dorian nears North Carolina coast as Category 1 hurricane
text:
CHARLESTON, S.C. – Parts of historic Market Street were under a foot of water, and gusting winds blew rain sideways Thursday as Hurricane Dorian continued its unrelenting advance on the U.S. coast, days after devastating parts of the Bahamas.

Hundreds of thousands of coastal residents of the Carolinas fled their homes and almost 250,000 homes and businesses across the region were without power.

The storm, which dropped to Category 1 status, was passing about about 30 miles south-southwest of Cape Lookout, North Carolina, at 2 a.m. Friday with maximum sustained winds at 90 mph, the National Hurricane Center said. Forecasters expect Dorian's center to move over or near North Carolina's coast overnight and Friday.

South Carolina officials said more than 440,000 people evacuated coastal areas. Flash floods did not overwhelm Charleston as much as anticipated, but Georgetown, Horry County and other areas north of the city will probably get more water, Gov. Henry McMaster said.

"It is still a very dangerous storm," McMaster said Thursday afternoon. "It is impossible to predict exactly where it is going to go and what is going to happen."

How to get involved: Havoc in the Bahamas. Here's how you can help.

The center of the storm was forecast to continue moving over or near North Carolina's coast, then weaken as it moves near the southeastern tip of New England on Friday night and Saturday morning.

The Outer Banks – the thin line of islands that stick out from North Carolina's coast – are particularly at risk, forecasters warned.

National Guardsmen check on Bay Tree subdivision in Little River, near North Myrtle Beach, S.C. after a tornado from Hurricane Dorian damaged the area on Sept. 5, 2019. More

The hurricane center said Charleston Harbor experienced wind gusts of nearly 80 mph. Gusts almost as strong were recorded elsewhere in the state and in North Carolina, the hurricane center said.

Several tornadoes were sighted in the area, according to the Storm Prediction Center. Hurricane-force winds extended up to 60 miles from the center, and tropical-storm-force winds extended up to 200 miles.

"People have to realize it’s not just about the center" of the storm, said Ken Graham, director of the hurricane center. "You have to look at the whole storm.”

Parts of North Carolina could see 7 feet of storm surge, he said. Anything above 3 feet is considered life-threatening, according to the hurricane center.

“They’re just going to continue to get more and more rain, so you’re going to get more street flooding, and some of the rivers could flood, as well,” Graham said.

North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper said the state opened more than 50 shelters and prepped more than 20 swift water rescue teams. Sixteen aircraft were at the ready.

In Wrightsville Beach, several people were charged with Class 2 misdemeanors after failing to comply with evacuation orders, Police Chief Daniel House said.

"You certainly put first responders at risk and your own life at risk if you decided to stay, particularly on a barrier island," Cooper said. "If they have not evacuated at this point, I'd get to the safest place I possibly could."

Cooper said a man fell to his death from a ladder while preparing his Columbus County home for the storm. At least 20 deaths in the Bahamas have been linked to Dorian.

In Charleston, at the corner of Calhoun and Washington streets near the state aquarium, John Rivers and daughters, Martha and Caroline, and son, Minott, raked tree debris out of storm drains.

"The city is doing the best job they can, but they can't be everywhere at every drain, so we're helping them out," Rivers said as the winds and rain carried debris down the street.
description: Hundreds of thousands of coastal residents of the Carolinas fled Thursday as Dorian continued its unrelenting march.
